posts.name: Kabir
posts.cooked: Past years’ data indicates a decline in the number of teams using LabVIEW. Over the span from 2016 to 2024, usage percentages show a consistent downward trend across most programming languages, with LabVIEW seeing particular drops. A detailed analysis reveals that the trend suggests an expected negative number of teams using LabVIEW this season. With uncertainty surrounding 2027, inquiries arise about 2025 usage patterns and motivations behind potential switches to LabVIEW. Additionally, there is curiosity about scenarios where LabVIEW surpasses the performance of Java, C++, or Python, particularly noting claims of easy live telemetry integration but lacking concrete examples.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Of the four officially supported languages, there isn’t much that distinguishes one over the others in terms of performance. Realistically, it comes down to personal knowledge and the level of support available from mentors. Areas dominated by NI/Emerson are likely to have strong mentor support for LabVIEW, making it a good choice for those teams. For others, selecting a language with excellent documentation and support, particularly third-party tools, is advisable, with Java currently leading in that regard.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: I don’t think LabView will make sense for any team regardless of context or mentor specialty in 2025.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: jedgar6
posts.cooked: Half the systems of research projects in college had labview.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: A decision can be both logical and incorrect.

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked: Every machine in the area I work in at Bridgestone has a NI/Labview system attached to it for monitoring certain processes. I very much avoid telling anyone that I know how to use that software.

posts.name: Landonh12
posts.cooked:
LabVIEW was used by 2468, 2687, and 2689 in 2025. Our mentors are proficient in it; I utilized LV during my time in FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC). Greg and Joe at NI also work with LV. Our students possess expertise and reusable code developed within LV. We independently created a path planner and a swerve library using this software.

Is LV the optimal choice? Many FRC programmers might argue against it due to limited publicly available code and tools alongside the programming language. While we face challenges such as code readability, deployment times, and platform requirements, these issues allow our students to develop solutions from scratch. This approach has been successful for us.

We are currently exploring alternative options if LV ceases to exist in 2027.

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked:
LabVIEW stands out compared to Java, C++, and Python in specific contexts, such as its ability to provide real-time telemetry capabilities and integrate seamlessly with hardware like CAN networks. While it may not offer unique advantages over widely-used languages in terms of performance, its specialized features make it particularly suited for robotics applications where real-time data processing and hardware integration are paramount. 

However, in an educational setting or for general-purpose programming, LabVIEW's learning curve and setup complexity often outweigh its benefits, making it less practical compared to simpler-to-learn alternatives.

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked: I used it one year back in 2018. Started a new team and that was the only language I knew how to use for FIRST Robotics Competition. It’s unreasonably slow, 2+ minute compile and deploy. No quick changes at all. Every year since then, we’ve used Java.

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: JohnFogarty mentions avoiding revealing his knowledge of software usage, which often leads to discussions about FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) and its associated hardware support. When talking about Labview compatibility for FRC competitions, many individuals express strong negative feelings toward Labview.

posts.name: Nick Seidl
posts.cooked: We are switching to Java for next year, but we've been a LabView team for a few years. I think the decision was originally made many years ago because someone assumed incorrectly that because of its graphical nature it was akin to FIRST Lego League and easier to learn. We had some mentor turnover over the years, and at one point the only mentor we had with programming experience was a mechanical engineer who had to learn LabView for some side quest at work. He recently asked to be relieved of his programming duties (is still an engineering mentor with us), so we are in the process of trying to recruit someone who can do Java.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: It provides our students with an opportunity to really dig in and write code and tools from scratch. Could you explain how your team’s use of LabView helps with this, in particular?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Mike
posts.cooked:
While we’ve been using Java for a while now, we mostly used LabView prior to around 2018.  

I enjoyed using it because you didn’t need to understand a programming language to use it. It’s not a huge portion of FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) students that end up pursuing careers involving coding full-time. However, some students will major in fields requiring significant coding, especially with experience in real-time control systems using languages like Java, C++, or Python. Even if most people don’t plan on writing large amounts of code post-high school, programming helps develop problem-solving, critical thinking, and hardware coordination skills. The advantage of programming and automation is that robots operate based solely on instructions given, regardless of their understanding of the real world. LabView simplified this process for students, allowing them to focus on logic without needing to master Java syntax first.  

One downside of LabView was its limited use with traditional programming languages. While transitioning from C++ to LabView was easier due to its graphical interface, many students now find LabView less useful compared to modern languages like Java or Python, which are widely adopted and supported. Since high schools typically don’t teach C++, students often find LabView’s visual approach more accessible than traditional coding. With exposure to Java or Python early on, the benefits of these languages and their extensive communities are now more apparent, making LabView feel outdated.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
I do miss the way that LabView let our students think about programming – as a flow of information into specific things and the outputs which flow out of them.  

I think dataflow languages are cool, but outside of pure signal-processing environments I think they’re mostly useful when paired with a text-based language for things that can’t be visually represented so neatly in 2 dimensions (which you almost certainly will encounter).  

I hope we eventually get a good tool for visual command composition. I’ve seen several community examples of block-based command code generators that look promising.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: We left LabVIEW primarily due to the extensive online documentation and tools available in the FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) space, even though Java offered comparable advantages. Contrarily, it's incorrect to say that LabVIEW lacks pre-written code—projects such as Swerve mechanisms, path planning solutions, and since approximately 2017/2018, a complete port of WPILib demonstrate otherwise. Additionally, while LabView isn't commonly taught in schools, its community is relatively small, and accessible resources are limited unless one has prior experience or connections within the LabView user community.

posts.name: Dan Nichols
posts.cooked:
We are exploring other options should LV not exist in 2027.  
I wonder if anyone has tried to use Simulink/MATLAB EmbeddedCoder to generate FRC-compatible C++? At least in my industry (automotive) model-based code in Simulink is a whole lot more common than anything NI. We have some little data collection systems that use a cRIO, but all the product work is hand code or generated-from-Simulink C/C++.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 548 Robostangs Electrical & Pneumatics Lead Mentor

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Matlab/Simulink had a beta test for FRC software around 2011 which didn't become part of competition use.

posts.name: Ethan C
posts.cooked: Reinventing the wheel may seem appealing due to its potential educational benefits, yet I believe it's not typically advisable for teams. Instead, utilizing more mainstream languages offers several advantages. By doing so, programmers can gain practical experience with widely-used tools, such as managing build systems they'll encounter in the future, recognizing common programming patterns, and working with third-party libraries from open-source projects.
